STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 23, 2022
Tina Smigelski
Alpena/Montmorency DHHS
711 West Chisholm Street
Alpena, MI 49707
RE: License #: CP040200941
Alpena/Montmorency DHHS
711 West Chisholm Street
Alpena, MI 49707
Dear Ms. Smigelski:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 08/03/2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Implementation, Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days
from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, the agency must identify why the previous CAP was
unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (734) 395-0920.
Sincerely,
Mark R. Hunter, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
411 Genesee
P.O. Box 5070
Saginaw, MI 48605
(989) 395-2847
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP040200941
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Alpena/Montmorency DHHS
Facility Address: 711 West Chisholm Street
Alpena, MI 49707
Facility Telephone #: (989) 354-7200
Original Issuance Date: 08/01/1991

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of the three foster home files reviewed indicated the recommendation for the
renewal of the license was not submitted at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license. In this example the foster home license
had an expiration date of 07/21/2022 and the report recommending renewal was
signed 07/20/2022.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED Previously cited Renewal 05/15/2021, CAP
Approved 06/02/2021.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
Two of the two special evaluations reviewed indicated the last names of children
placed in the home that were a part of the evaluation were included in the special
evaluation report. The dates of the special evaluations were 04/10/2022 and
07/16/2021 respectively.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
4

One of the two special evaluations reviewed did not include documentation the
foster parent was provided a copy of the special evaluation upon its completion. The
special evaluation was dated 07/16/2021. The agency typically sends a cover letter
to the foster parent along with the report as documentation, but this letter was not
located at the time of this review.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she has a
right to have his or her written response included as an
attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
One of the two special evaluations reviewed did not include documentation the
foster parent was provided a copy of the special evaluation upon its completion. The
special evaluation was dated 07/16/2021. The agency typically sends a cover letter
to the foster parent along with the report as documentation, but this letter was not
located at the time of this review. The letter typically includes a statement for the
foster parent regarding the right to include a written response as an attachment.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
Two of the two special evaluations reviewed did not include documentation the
social services worker with children placed in the home was provided a copy of the
special evaluation as required by this rule. The special evaluations were dated
04/10/2022 and 07/16/2021 respectively.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed corrective
action plan, all social service workers who have children placed
in the home shall be notified there is a corrective action plan
and what is required of the foster parent in that plan.
Two of the two special evaluations reviewed required corrective action plans and
there was no documentation the social services worker with children placed in the
home was notified of the requirements of the corrective action plans. The special
evaluations were dated 04/10/2022 and 07/16/2021 respectively.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(4) If an emergency change in placement is necessary, then all
of the documentation required in subrules (2) and (3) of this rule
5

shall be in the child's record within 14 calendar days after the
change in placement.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed had at least one change in
placement that was not documented as required by this rule. The foster care record
for this youth indicated changes in placement 09/12/2021, 09/17/2021, 02/11/2022,
and 02/23/2022. The required DHHS 69s required to document these changes were
not located at the time of this evaluation.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
One of the six foster child records reviewed did not include documentation the foster
child had completed an updated physical within the time frame established by this
rule. In this example the last physical for this youth was dated 12/02/2020 with an
updated physical due to be completed by 02/02/2022. Documentation of an updated
physical was not located at the time of this review.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two of the six foster child records reviewed indicated at least one updated service
plan was not completed within the time frame established by this rule. In the first
example the youth had an updated service plan with a time period ending
04/19/2022 that was completed 04/26/2022. The second youth had an updated
service plan with a time period ending 10/09/2021 that was completed 10/27/2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED Previously cited Renewal 05/15/2021, CAP
Approved 06/02/2021.
R 400.12422 Foster care record.
(3) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(e) Change of placement documentation as required by R
400.12405.
Two of the four closed foster child records reviewed did not include change in
placement documentation as required by this rule. The identified closure dates for
6

these two changes were 06/23/2022 and 02/03/2022 respectively. The DHHS 69
forms used to document these changes were not located at the time of this review.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days
The one independent living record reviewed included one updated service plan that
was completed outside the time frame required by this rule. In this example the
time period ended 07/30/2021 and the updated service plan was not completed
until 09/22/2021. It was reported at the time of the exit conference this appeared to
be the consequence of a staff member who is no longer employed with this agency.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before a
youth is placed in independent living:
(a) How the youth meets the eligibility requirements for
the specific program the youth is being placed into.
(b) The basis for concluding that a youth exhibits self-
care potential.
(c) That the youth’s social service worker has personally
observed and determined that the living situation is safe
and that the youth has a bed and has access to cooking
and bathing facilities.
(d) The availability of specific and relevant resources
that may provide for suitable social, physical,
educational, vocational, and emotional needs of a youth.
(e) An evaluation of a youth's need for supervision and a
plan for providing the level of supervision determined
necessary.
(f) Proof that financial support to meet the youth’s
housing, clothing, food, and miscellaneous expenses is
available.
The one independent living record reviewed did not include documentation of the
eligibility requirements identified by this rule. In this example the youth had an
identified independent living placement date of 05/20/2020. Although this
documentation could not be located the most recent updated service plan dated
04/26/2022 indicated the youth is doing exceptionally well in his independent living
placement.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
7

(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service
worker and the youth in independent living at least once
each month at a youth's place of residence.
The one independent living record reviewed did not include documentation that a
January 2022 visitation had been completed as required by this rule.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED Previously cited Renewal 05/15/2021,
CAP Approved 06/02/2021.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between
the youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
(b) A plan for education or work.
(c) An agreement for the youth to meet with the worker at
least one time per calendar month.
(d) The location where the youth is living.
The one independent living record reviewed did not include documentation that a
mutually agreed upon contract had been developed as required by this rule.
Updated service plans were completed to review the progress of the youth in his
independent living placement but these reviews did not include the
development/review of an independent living contract. The youth was placed in
independent living effective 05/20/2020.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
MISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22). DHHS will maintain an operational
statewide automated child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which
will be the primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
A review of the MISACWIS system as a part of this evaluation indicated not all of
the information required had been uploaded into the information system. The most
common omissions involved Parent Agency Treatment Plans (PATP) that had
signatures as required and Updated Service Plans (USP) that had signatures as
required.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
8

included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-6B Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for the
following:
Completing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, checking it for
accuracy, identifying areas needing follow-up, and recording the outcome
data.
Five of the seven foster care records reviewed including the independent living
record had at least one Family Team Meeting (FTM) completed that did not include
documentation/completion of the DHHS-1105 as required. The first record had
five documented FTMs completed with no completed DHHS-1105s. The second
record had one FTM completed with no completed DHHS-1105. The third record
had five completed FTMs with three having no completed DHHS-1105s. The
fourth record had four completed FTMs and only one DHHS-1105 completed. The
fifth record had four completed FTMs and only one completed DHHS-1105.
FOM 801-03 All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's current and
complete health information.
Two of the six foster child records reviewed did not include documentation the
medical passport of the youth was updated/maintained at least quarterly. At the
time of this review the first example had the most recent signature dated
06/06/2021 and the second record had a most recent signature date of 10/04/2021.
Each record indicated additional services had been provided since the time of the
most recent signatures.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
None
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
None
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan for the renewal
evaluation completed 05/05/2021. Areas identified in noncompliance as a part of
9

that evaluation were FOM 722-03 C, FOM 722-08 E, FOM 722-16, FOM 722-061,
FOM 722-06H, FOM 722-08C, ISEP 6.33, ISEP 6.12 (a)(b), 324(8), 418(2)(b),
502(2), 503(3), and 505(2)(a). The corrective action plan was approved 06/02/2021.
Areas identified as repeat noncompliance as a part of this interim evaluation are
324(8), 505(2)(a), and 418(2)(b).
Trends and Repeat Violation Assessment
The agency has made reasonable efforts to address the areas of noncompliance
and has demonstrated progress in dealing with noncompliance and ensuring
progress in maintaining compliance in most areas. Although there are 17 violations
cited in this inspection, it is notable that five are related to the two special
evaluations reviewed and four were related to the one independent living file
reviewed. The agency should spend time focusing on those two areas.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment included a review of the corrective action plan
that was implemented to address areas of noncompliance in the renewal evaluation
completed 05/05/2021. It also presented the impact of staffing changes and noted
the tools being used to monitor the agency’s practices and procedures.
Interviews
Child Welfare staff participated in entrance and exit conferences and there were no
identified concerns.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
08/19/2022
________________________________________
Mark R. Hunter Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 22, 2022
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Area Manager
